IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
On Saturday, 11/18/2023 at approximately 0725, the Maryland State Police – College Park Barrack initiated an armed carjacking investigation in Prince George’s County, MD.  Investigation revealed the victim, Jonathan Hernandez, was traveling on Rt. 198 near Old Gunpowder Road in a white 2000 Honda SUV displaying MD registration: 2Z44726.  While stopped at a red light, Hernandez was approached by the suspect who produced a handgun and pressed it against the rear of his head through the open rear-passenger window.   The suspect forced the victim from the Honda at gun-point, entered the Honda, and then drove from the scene.  The victim’s wallet and cellular telephone were both inside of the Honda and were also taken by the suspect as he fled the scene in the vehicle.  The victim was able to respond to a local business where he made contact with police dispatch.
 
Shortly thereafter the College Park Barrack was contacted by the Montgomery County Police Department indicating they had located the Honda which had been carjacked.  It was learned they had received a call of a motor vehicle collision and, upon arrival, confirmed it to be the previously described Honda SUV.  The Honda was later taken to Montgomery County Police – District 4 for storage pending follow-up investigation.  Montgomery County Police were able to locate the driver / suspect on foot in the area of the collision.  The suspect was identified as Ira Shaw-Bates.  A witness to the collision was interviewed by Montgomery County Police and identified the individual, Shaw-Bates, as the sole subject inside of the Honda.  The area in which the subject fled and was located was preliminarily checked for the firearm with no results. 
 
Shaw-Bates was transported to the College Park Barrack for further investigation and processing.  While at the Barrack a search of Shaw-Bates was conducted which revealed two plastic “flip-top” vials which contained a small amount of white powder-substance, consistent with that of cocaine hydrochloride.  Further search of Shaw-Bates revealed a black Carhartt ski-mask as well as six “simunition” or “air-soft” style rounds of ammunition.  Investigators recognized both the rounds and ski mask to be items often used in, and consistent with, armed carjacking, robbery, and related types of crimes. 

D/Sgt. Heath made contact with the victim Hernandez at the College Park Barrack.  During interview Hernandez provided a nearly identical statement as previously described.  When asked if he could identify the victim if observed again, Hernandez stated he would be unable to.  This eliminated the possibility of a phot-array or “show-up” identification as initially planned by D/Sgt. Heath.  Hernandez signed a MSP consent-to-search form allowing D/Sgt. Heath access to his vehicle stored at the Montgomery County Police Department.   

While at the Barrack Shaw-Bates was advised of his Miranda Rights by D/Sgt. Heath and declined to speak with investigators. 

D/Sgt. Heath then conducted a follow-up phone interview with the witness identified by the Montgomery County Police Department.  George Schrader was contacted at the provided telephone number of 724-984-3602.  Schrader stated while traveling in his vehicle he observed a crashed white Honda CRV and initially did not see any occupants of the vehicle.  After initially driving past the collision he turned around and returned.  At that time Schrader observed a black male, appx. 5’09” – 5’10” wearing a red coat and black hoodie at the rear of the Honda in the trunk area.  The male was using the light of a cellular telephone to look through the vehicle and, after initially being at the trunk area, the male returned to the driver seat area.  When Schrader was observed by the male he stated he “was good” and then fled the scene on foot into a wooded area. 

It should be noted the clothing and physical description provided by Schrader matched Shaw-Bates.  Additionally, his shoes were wet and covered in grass and mud consistent with him running through a wooded area as described by Schrader.  His clothing was later photographed by Tpr. Fleming.
 
Shaw-Bates was queried through the Maryland Gun Center and it was learned he is prohibited from possession of firearms and / or ammunition.  Prohibiting factors include: under 30 years of age with juvenile adjudication of a disqualifying crime, conviction of a misdemeanor with two or more years of imprisonment, conviction of a disqualifying crime classified as a felony, and conviction of a crime of violence.  

D/Sgt. Heath later responded to the Honda CRV during which time Hernandez’s MD driver’s license was located within a black wallet, consistent with Hernandez’s statements.  It should be noted that, due to the severe damage to the Honda, a full inventory of the vehicle could not be completed.  It is possible that a firearm could be contained within the Honda and is inaccessible due to the damages.

Shaw-Bates was later charged by Tpr. Fleming and transported to PGDOC pending initial appearance. 

In days following the arrest, Tpr. Fleming was contacted by Hernandez who stated he had used a phone tracking application for his device.  The location given was PGDOC in Upper Marlboro, MD.  This led investigators to believe the phone in Shaw-Bates’ personal items during his arrest was, in-fact, Hernandez’s.  Tpr. Fleming has made several attempts to retrieve the phone and has not been granted access by PGDOC.  Corrections and supervisory staff remain uncooperative in allowing her to obtain the phone as evidence.

This concludes my portion of investigation.  Tpr. Fleming remains as primary and additional support will be provided as necessary.

Case closed by arrest.

Q-13 IS EQUIPPED WITH AN IN CAR CAMERA
THE INCIDENT WAS VISUALLY AND AUDIBLY RECORDED

SHAW-BATES, IRA // 23-MSP-040863 // D05CR23001341

Defendant: Shaw-Bates, Ira
Incident Number: 23-MSP-040863
Date of Offense: 11/18/2023
Arresting Officer: Tpr. Fleming #7439

Victim(s):
Hernandez, Jonathan
State of Maryland

Witness:
Schrader, George

CHARGES:
CR 3-405(b)(1) ...did obtain unauthorized possession and control of a motor vehicle, to wit: white Honda CR-V, from Jonathan Hernandez who was then and there in actual possession of the motor vehicle, by placing said individual in fear through intimidation, threat of force, and threat of violence.
CR 3-405(c)(1) ...did obtain unauthorized possession and control of a motor vehicle, to wit: white Honda CR-V from Jonathan Hernandez who was then and there in actual possession of the motor vehicle by placing said individual in fear through intimidation, threat of force, and threat of violence and display a dangerous weapon during the commission of the carjacking.
CR 3-402 ...did unlawfully and feloniously rob Jonathan Hernandez of cell phone and wallet.
CR 7-105 ...did unlawfully, knowingly, and willfully take out of Jonathan Hernandez's lawful custody, control, and use, a motor vehicle, to wit: white Honda CR-V, without the consent of said Jonathan Hernandez, in violation of CR 7-105, of the Annotated Code of Maryland.
CR 7-203 ...did without permission, take and carry away from the premises, out of the control, and from the use of Jonathan Hernandez a motor vehicle, to wit: white Honda CR-V with the intent to temporarily deprive Jonathan Hernandez of the use and possession of said property.
CR 5-601(a)(1) ...did possess a controlled dangerous substance of schedule II, to wit: cocaine.
CR 5-619(c)(2) …did possess with intent to use drug paraphernalia, to wit: plastic vials, used to store, contain, and conceal a controlled dangerous substance of Schedule II, to wit: cocaine.
CR 4-204 ...did use a firearm in the commission of a crime of violence/ felony
PS 5-133(c) ...did possess a regulated firearm after having been convicted of a crime of violence as defined in CR 14-101.

CRIME SCENE PROCESSING:
A search of Shaw-Bates person was conducted at the Maryland State Police College Park “Q” barrack. Two plastic “flip-top” vials containing a small amount of white powder-substance, consistent with that of cocaine hydrochloride was located. The CDS was placed on Property Records “P-341229” and was processed according to Maryland State Police policy. The property was put into the Barrack “Q” CDS Temporary Storage on November 18th, 2023. I have been trained in the identification of CDS to include cocaine and paraphernalia. I have affected several arrests for violations of CDS laws and have seen those subjects successfully convicted in courts of law. I recognized the above listed CDS and paraphernalia based upon my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper.
Further search of Shaw-Bates revealed a black Carhartt ski-mask as well as six “simunition” or “air-soft” style rounds of ammunition. I processed the rounds and ski-mask according to Maryland State Police policy. The evidence was put into the Barrack “Q” Property Room on November 18th, 2023. I recognized the rounds to be consistent in size and dimension with those of handgun caliber ammunition. I further recognized both the rounds and ski mask to be items often used in, and consistent with, armed carjacking, robbery, and related types of crimes. Further search of Shaw-Bates revealed Hernandez’s phone.
Shaw-Bates was advised of his Miranda Rights. Shaw-Bates declined to speak with Troopers
The Honda CR-V was taken to Montgomery County Police – District 4 for storage pending follow-up investigation. The vehicle was processed by D/Sgt. Heath #4437.

NARRATIVE:
On November 18th, 2023 at approximately 0725 hours, the Maryland State Police College Park “Q” Barrack initiated an armed carjacking investigation in Prince George’s County, Maryland.
Due to calls for service and limited manpower, the victim was transported to the Maryland State Police College Park “Q” Barrack where he was interviewed by investigators.
The victim was identified as Hernandez, Jonathan (5/M, DOB: 01/31/1991). Investigation revealed Hernandez was traveling on Route 198 near Old Gunpowder Road in a white 2000 Honda CR-V displaying Maryland registration “2Z4726”. While stopped at a red light, Hernandez was approached by the suspect who produced a handgun and pressed it against the rear of his head through the open rear-passenger window. The suspect forced the victim from the vehicle at gun-point, entered the vehicle, and drove from the scene. The suspect was described by Hernandez as a 1/M wearing a red coat. The victim’s wallet and cellular telephone were both inside of the Honda and were also taken by the suspect as he fled the scene in the vehicle. The victim was able to respond to a local business where he made contact with Prince George’s County Police dispatch at approximately 0615 hours. (Related PGCO Incident #: PP23111800000348)
At approximately 0741 hours the Maryland State Police College Park “Q” Barrack was contacted by the Montgomery County Police Department indicating they had located the stolen vehicle. (Related MOCO Incident #: 23-0067037)
It was learned Montgomery County Police Department had received a call of a motor vehicle collision in the area of Norbeck Road and Layhill Road. Upon their arrival, officers confirmed it to be the previously described Honda CR-V. The vehicle was unattended. The vehicle was later taken to Montgomery County Police – District 4 for storage pending follow-up investigation.
A witness to the collision was interviewed and described the suspect as a 1/M wearing a red jacket and jeans. The witness was identified as Schrader, George Matthew (2/M, DOB: 01/30/1988). Schrader further stated that when the suspect observed Schrader on the phone with Montgomery County Police he fled into the woods on foot.
While canvasing the area, officers observed a 1/M matching Schrader’s description walking westbound towards Georgia Avenue. Officers detained the subject. The suspect was identified by Schrader to be the sole occupant of the Honda CR-V.
The suspect was treated while on scene of the collision for his injuries by Montgomery County EMS. Montgomery County EMS personnel confirmed the suspect did not need to be transported to hospital. The suspect refused transport to hospital. (Related MOCO EMS #: 2300157982, 2300157991)
Due to calls for service and limited manpower, the suspect was transported to the Maryland State Police College Park “Q” Barrack. The suspect was identified as Shaw-Bates, Ira (1/M, DOB: 08/01/2002).
Shaw-Bates wore a large red puffer jacket over a black zip-up jacket. Shaw-Bates was wearing black pants with multiple zippers as well as purple camouflage high-top shoes. Shaw-Bates’s clothing matched both the victim’s and witness’s description of the suspect.
The suspect had a cut above his left eyebrow and walked with a limp. These injuries were consistent with having been involved in a motor vehicle collision where there was heavy damage to the front of the vehicle.
On November 18th, 2023 at approximately 0725 hours, Shaw-Bates was arrested for armed carjacking based on the totality of circumstances.

CRIME SCENE PROCESSING:
Shaw-Bates was queried through the Maryland Gun Center. It was learned he is prohibited from possession of firearms and/or ammunition. Prohibiting factors include: under 30 years of age with juvenile adjudication of a disqualifying crime, conviction of a misdemeanor with two or more years of imprisonment, conviction of a disqualifying crime classified as a felony, and conviction of a crime of violence.
Shaw-Bates was processed and charged with the above listed charges. Shaw-Bates was transported to Bowie State Medical Center where he was further treated for any injuries. Shaw-Bates was discharged from Bowie State Medical Center and transported to Upper Marlboro DOC. Shaw-Bates was released to the custody of Upper Marlboro DOC at approximately 1756 hours.
All criminal offenses occurred in Prince George’s County, Maryland. Apprehension of the defendant occurred in Montgomery County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: Two gold plastic vials containing trace amounts of white powder residue.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
NARRATIVE:

     On 11/18/2023 at after 0700 hours, I, Corporal Michael Kemp #5753 was the Duty Officer at the Maryland State Police College Park Barracks, when Mr. Jonathan Hernandez (Male DOB 01/31/1991) arrived at the barracks to report an armed carjacking.  Hernandez advised he was operating his Honda SUV (MD tag 2Z4726) on Sandy Spring Rd near Old Gunpowder Rd, in Prince George's County.  While stopped at a red light, he was approached by a subject/suspect who placed a handgun to the back of his head through the open rear drivers side window, and then forced him out of the vehicle at gun point.  The suspect was described as a black male wearing a red coat.  The suspect then left the scene in the victim's car which still had his wallet and phone inside it.  

     I was then contacted by Sgt Anderson of the Montgomery County Police Department who advised they were on the scene of a motor vehicle collision involving the white Honda SUV, which was a vehicle that was just involved in an armed carjacking.  The operator fled the scene of the crash, but a black male with a red coat, was located in the area near the crash who was detained by Montgomery County Police Department.  That subject was transported to the MSP College Park Barracks.  I, Corporal Kemp, later identified the suspect as Ira Shaw-bates (African American Male/DOB 08/04/2002).  He had a bandage on his forehead from emergency medical services prior to his arrival at the barrack and advised he refused further treatment.  He was then searched, and placed into a holding cell pending further investigation.  I then contacted Detective Sergeant Heath, who responded to the barrack to assist with the criminal investigation.   

This crime occurred in Prince George's County, Maryland.
